The fortlets not being very far distant from one another, the repeated explosions of guns quickly signifies the approach of an enemy descried from afar, to the metropolis itself. As this province is destitute of a regular soldiery, the settlers themselves are ordered sometimes to watch in these fortlets, sometimes 'to march against the savages. Being every year pressed for some months with the burdens of the militia, they are forced, during frequent and long absenceS, to neglect their substance, their fa- milies, their agriculture, and their commerce. In this you may see the chief origin of their poverty. Besides the equestrian savageS, Who is ignorant of the calamities brought upon this province by the barbarous Payaguas? These atrocious pirateS, infesting the rivers Paraguay and Parana, had for many years been in the habit of intercepting Spanish vessels freighted with wares for the port of Buenos-Ayres, or conveying them from thence, and of massaering the creWS.
